data.title: A Complete List of Book Tropes: Everything You Need to Know
data.meta_description: Here's a list of the best book tropes for each major genre. Learn what readers expect from your book and how to use them.
data.text:
Whether we realize it or not, we seek out certain tropes when we're searching for a new novel to read. If someone recommends a book to us, we want to know what it's about in broad terms. And these broad terms often include not just the genre, but also the common tropes used in the story.

Every reader has their tropes of choice. Some may have a broad range of preferred tropes, while others may only stick to a handful.

And as a writer, it's essential to get to know the most common tropes both in and out of your genres. Go straight to the source by finding out which Amazon Categories you want to target, and researching what tropes are popular for your story.

Plus, you'll learn in this complete list of book tropes what can also apply to your book.

Literary Tropes vs Genre Tropes

Before we get to the list, I need to clear something up. The tropes we'll be talking about today aren't literary tropes, which include things like irony, metaphor, and hyperbole, to name a few.

No, we'll be discussing tropes in the more modern sense of the word as they pertain to fiction.

In short, a trope is a plot structure, theme, storyline, character trait, motif, or plot device that is commonly used in storytelling. Whether you mean to or not, you use tropes in your writing. We all do. And that's why it's so important to study them. Because once you know your tropes, you can use them (or avoid them) to please your readers.

Format Beautiful Professional Books

Easy to use, and and full of amazing features, you can quickly turn your book into a professional book.

Check It Out

Are Tropes Good or Bad?

You‚Äôll often hear people disparaging tropes as something to be avoided. Like most writing advice, this should be taken with a grain of salt. Tropes exist for a reason‚Äîbecause people respond to them. That‚Äôs not to say that you should mindlessly use any trope you recognize. As a writer, part of your art is providing stories that are unique but not so unique as to be unrecognizable as a thriller or a romance or whatever genre you write in.

Tropes change over time, and that‚Äôs a good thing. But they only change when writers dare to use them in different ways‚Äîor create new tropes that readers love.

So as we move through this list of book tropes, keep that in mind. They‚Äôre neither good nor bad. It‚Äôs how you use a trope that matters.

I'll mention a bit about them and try to break them down into the most common genres. (Spoiler alert: romance has a lot of tropes.)

Let's get to it.

How Do Tropes Affect Book Sales?

Many readers start with tropes when looking for their next book. So, if your book includes a trope that many readers enjoy, you increase its chances of being discovered. This is because readers will type these tropes directly into the Amazon search bar- looking for things like ‚ÄúMagical Creatures‚Äù, ‚ÄúEnemies To Lovers‚Äù, ‚ÄúTwist Ending‚Äù, and more.

Before writing your book, it's important to see which tropes are popular among readers. Having a well sought after trope can help your book appear in more places on Amazon, meaning more people will find your story. A top quality book that appears high in trope search results is a recipe for success.

Fortunately, with a little research, it's easy to see which tropes are being actively searched for on the Amazon store. Use this to your advantage to attract more readers.

For example, if you are writing a Romance book, you can use the search result earnings for common tropes to estimate their popularity.

Data provided by Publisher Rocket

This type of research can apply to all genres- so be sure to dig in and find out if there is a hungry audience for the tropes in your story. Once you have your trope, you can also use keyword research to maximize its effectivity.

Find and Discover Profitable Tropes

Over 72,000+ authors, NYT bestsellers, and publishing companies use Publisher Rocket to find the most profitable book tropes readers crave ‚Äì you can too.

For example, say you are writing a Fantasy book about magical creatures. Well, you may want to research which of those beasts are most popular in the market, in order to help determine your cover design and specific keywords. With earnings for different magical creatures, you can immediately see that some keywords within a trope are far more popular than others:

Data provided by Publisher Rocket

So‚Ä¶ when you look into tropes, be sure to consider how you can use their popularity, because it can have a big impact on sales.

Complete List of Book Tropes

While I've done my best to piece these tropes together in genres, it's important to note that many of them are used across many genres.

Just because you see a trope under a certain heading doesn't mean you can't use it in another genre. After all, the best way to please readers is by giving them a story that's at once both familiar and fresh. And a great way to do this is by mixing multiple tropes.

Just make sure you do your research first because there are certain tropes that are expected in certain genres (happily ever after in romance stories, for example).

Action & Adventure Tropes

Action and Adventure tropes can also be found in Fantasy, Thriller, Mystery, and Science Fiction stories.

Hidden Treasure

Puzzle Solving

Exotic Locations

‚ÄúUnbreakable‚Äù Codes ‚Äì That are broken by the protagonist.

Ancient Secrets

High Action ‚Äì The action is what readers come for, so it‚Äôs important to have plenty of it. From explosions and gunfights to car chases and hand-to-hand combat.

The Larger-Than-Life Threat ‚Äì A city, a country, or the whole world will blow up if the protagonist fails.

Military Exploits ‚Äì Military thrillers are often found in both action/adventure and thriller genres. Often, these novels follow a small group of professional soldiers.

The Love Interest ‚Äì There almost always is one, and it usually helps drive the plot.

Linear Plotlines

Black-and-White Morality

The MacGuffin ‚Äì An object that acts as a plot device to move the story along. The hero must find the MacGuffin(s) before the villain does in order to save the world.

The Double-Cross ‚Äì A trusted ally or side character turns out to be working for the enemy.

Bad Guys Who Can't Aim ‚Äì No matter how many shots they fire at the hero, he never gets hit.

Children's Book Tropes

Children's books aim to impart a lesson to the little readers. But there are some common tropes that work well in these shorter stories.

Talking Animals

The Power of Friendship

Appreciating Our Differences ‚Äì Anything from race to preferences to religious differences.

The Defective Animal ‚Äì A hurt or deformed animal that needs to be cared for.

Dealing With Adversity ‚Äì Often, the protagonist fails twice and then gets it right on the third attempt.

Learning a New Skill

Learning About Family ‚Äì Usually a new sibling.

Learning to Share

Loyalty

Dedication

Dealing With Anger ‚Äì Or any other powerful emotion.

Going to School

The Power of Imagination

The Power of Teamwork

Compassion

Courage

Bravery

Honesty

Growing Up

Dealing With Loss

Contemporary Fiction

Contemporary fiction stories don't fit nicely into popular fiction genres. This is largely because the tropes are often hard to identify (or nonexistent). But there are a few you'll often see in these literary fiction books.

Set in the Modern Day

Conflict Comes from Interpersonal Relationships

Family Drama

Coming of Age

Dealing with Mental Illness, Addiction, Sexual Orientation, and/or Abuse

Unresolved Endings Are Common

Lack of Common Plot Structure

No Otherworldly Elements

A Death in the Family

Fantasy

If you've watched any of the Lord of the Rings movies or read any of the books, you can probably name a few common Fantasy tropes.

The Hero's Journey ‚Äì A plot structure popularized by Joseph Campbell that's often used in Fantasy stories. Sometimes called a Quest.

Side Quests ‚Äì While on the way to accomplish their main goal, the characters get sidetracked or split up to accomplish smaller goals so they can then tackle their larger goal.

Medieval-Adjacent Settling ‚Äì Without all the magic, it could be Europe during the middle ages.

The Chosen One ‚Äì A protagonist that's prophesied to be the savior of Earth (or whatever fictional world the story is set on).

The Evil One ‚Äì A larger-than-life villain that usually has immense supernatural powers. Often a wizard, witch, or warlock.

The Mentor ‚Äì An older character who helps the protagonist along on his or her journey. Sometimes a good wizard, witch, or warlock.

Powerful Artifacts ‚Äì Swords, talismans, staffs, rings, etc. These items are powerful, and everyone wants them.

Magical Creatures

Epic Storylines With Lots of Characters ‚Äì This is often expected, especially in high fantasy.

High Stakes (Good vs Evil)

Heir to the Throne ‚Äì The character may not want the throne or even know that he/she is the heir. But by the end of the story, they usually take their rightful place as a benevolent ruler.

Best of the Best ‚Äì Whether the protagonist or antagonist (or both), these characters prove themselves to be the best at whatever skills they have.

Unlikely Allies ‚Äì When the hero is forced to trust one of their enemies to save the day.

The Reluctant Hero ‚Äì When the protagonist just wants to be left alone but is pulled into the adventure, anyway.

Rescued by the Cavalry ‚Äì Sometimes, this is an actual army riding over the ridge. Other times, it‚Äôs an ally showing up at just the right time.

The Damsel in Distress ‚Äì Not as popular these days, but still used on occasion.

The Training Sequence ‚Äì Where the reluctant hero learns to fight, harness magic, use his new knowledge, or all of the above.

Paying the Price ‚Äì Victory doesn‚Äôt come easily for the protagonist in my fantasy stories. There‚Äôs usually a price to pay.

Historical Fiction

Historical fiction, in this case, is not primarily romance. That is, there can be a romance subplot, but it's not the main storyline. These are all pretty self-explanatory.

War ‚Äì Often set During World War II

Set in Colonial America

Combining Real and Fictional Events

Including Historical Figures as Characters

Religious Themes

Social and Political Turmoil

Dual Timeline ‚Äì One in the past, one in the present.

Traveling Long Distances ‚Äì Like moving to the West Coast during the 18th century.

What Life Was Like ‚Äì Showing the everyday life of people in historical settings.

Horror

Horror books come in all shapes and sizes, but there are certain tropes that readers love (or love to hate). Here are some of the biggest ones.

Mysterious Things Are Happening ‚Äì And usually, people are dying because of them.

Cursed Items ‚Äì From books to dolls to religious trinkets, there's often something that's cursed.

Monsters ‚Äì There are plenty to choose from or you can invent your own.

Aliens ‚Äì Abductions, invasions, awakenings. It‚Äôs all rife with terror.

Glowing Eyes ‚Äì They usually appear in the darkness at a time of great tension.

Humans Can be Evil ‚Äì Not all monsters look gruesome. Some live next door.

Bad Things Happen at Night ‚Äì Rarely in the daytime.

Paralyzed With Fear ‚Äì When a character can‚Äôt move, speak, or scream.

The Antichrist ‚Äì Bad news for the world.

Cults and Religious Extremists ‚Äì Often trying to unleash demons or the Antichrist.

Backing into Darkness ‚Äì You can bet there‚Äôs something lurking there.

Traumatic Past ‚Äì May help the character deal with the traumatic present.

Minority Character Dies First ‚Äì Perhaps a good one to subvert.

Severed Limbs ‚Äì Usually found by other characters.

Losing the Ability to Run ‚Äì When a character trips at the exact wrong time.

Easily Definable Characters ‚Äì The mean jock, the promiscuous girl, the alcoholic cop, etc. Otherwise known as character archetypes.

Karmic Retribution ‚Äì In a lot of horror stories, karma is swift in taking out those who do evil.

Deal With the Devil

Creepy Settings ‚Äì Abandoned places, graveyards, forests, etc.

The Unhappy Ending ‚Äì This is one of the few genres where you could possibly get away with killing your protagonist off (if done right).

The World is Ending

Defeated Monster Comes Back to Life ‚Äì Right at the end of the book.

Literary

Although a broad category encompassing books that don't fit well into other genres, there are some common tropes in Literary Fiction.

Flowery Writing Matters More Than Plot ‚Äì Many readers seek these books out for a certain feeling or experience related to the writing itself rather than the plot.

Childhood Memories ‚Äì Dealing with childhood trauma is common in literary fiction.

Set in a Small Town

Major Characters Killed Off ‚Äì There‚Äôs no guarantee of a happy ending in this broad genre. That means that even major characters can die.

Dysfunctional Family

Meandering Plot ‚Äì Once again, plot isn‚Äôt a major concern. Many of these books end ambiguously or abruptly.

Mystery

A good mystery pulls the reader along, asking them to solve the case before the protagonist does. There are common tropes that most readers expect when they pick up a mystery.

The Unlikable Victim ‚Äì Common in cozy mysteries, the unlikable victim is someone who was an all-around jerk. But their killer still must be brought to justice. The problem is, everyone has a motive!

The Red Herring ‚Äì This is the character who we're led to believe is the killer, but it's a misdirection. This can also be a clue that points in the wrong direction.

Close Quarters ‚Äì Whether the setting is a train, a boat, or a mansion during a bad storm, it's common for all the suspects to be in close quarters while the detective tries to unravel the mystery.

The Alibi ‚Äì Just when the protagonist thought they had the killer, an airtight alibi comes to light.

Outsmarting the Criminal ‚Äì When the protagonist hatches a brilliant plan to get the criminal to confess.

The Trophy ‚Äì When the killer keeps evidence that turns out to be his/her undoing.

The Protagonist is a Suspect ‚Äì What happens when the detective (amateur or professional) is the number one suspect? Lots of tension, that's what.

Righting Past Wrongs ‚Äì It's common for the protagonist to take a case that directly or indirectly relates to a previous failure. They get a second chance to right their past wrong.

The Dramatic Reveal ‚Äì When a character holds back information for some reason until revealing it in the most dramatic fashion possible.

A Detective with a Haunted Past

Consulting a Criminal ‚Äì When one criminal (usually already caught) is consulted to glean information to catch the protagonist.

Amnesia ‚Äì Your main character can't remember who they are or can't recall vital information pertaining to the case.

Twist Ending ‚Äì Many readers love a good twist ending at the end of a mystery.

Romance

With so many romance subgenres, there are plenty of popular tropes to choose from. Most romance novels have several of the following tropes in them.

Happy Ending ‚Äì The most popular and important romance trope on the list!

The Love Triangle ‚Äì Three characters, one choice, and some unavoidable hurt feelings. Love triangles make for plenty of tension.

Forced Proximity ‚Äì Two characters who find love when they're forced to spend time together.

Forbidden Love ‚Äì Romeo and Juliet, but without the tragic ending and made with the modern romance reader in mind.

The Enemies to Lovers Trope ‚Äì The characters start out hating each other. But true love prevails. (Often combined with the Forced Proximity trope).

Fake Relationship ‚Äì One character ropes another into posing as their partner ‚Äì often to get a nagging relative off their back. But what starts out as pretend soon turns serious in this popular trope.

The Other Woman/Man ‚Äì Be careful with this one. No one likes a cheater, which is why there‚Äôs often some ‚Äúlegitimate‚Äù reason for being unfaithful to the partner.

Incapable of Love ‚Äì That character who has been hurt so bad they‚Äôve given up on love. Until . . .

Love Is the Answer ‚Äì It doesn‚Äôt matter what the question is.

The Pure and the Promiscuous ‚Äì One character (often a female) is inexperienced in the ways of love. The other (often a male) is overly experienced. You know the rest. Perhaps a trope that‚Äôs antiquated and certainly problematic in today‚Äôs culture.

Love at First Glimpse (Instalove) ‚Äì The characters don‚Äôt need to get to know each other to see if they‚Äôre compatible. They fall in love without even talking. The rest of the story is usually a ‚Äúwill they won‚Äôt they‚Äù plotline.

Marriage of Convenience ‚Äì There's no love between this couple. At least, not at first. But as the two get to know each other, they soon discover the sparks.

Unexpected Love Interest ‚Äì While the protagonist goes on date after date with the wrong people, their friend is always there for support. Pretty soon, the main character realizes that the ‚Äúfriend‚Äù is the one they've loved all along.

Fated Mates ‚Äì In the paranormal romance genre, the fated mates trope is where two soulmates (one usually a shifter) find each other and things soon get steamy.

The Misunderstanding ‚Äì It‚Äôs not all sunshine and rainbows in romance stories. There needs to be a conflict that comes to a head near the end of the book. This conflict is often predicated on a simple misunderstanding. This is one trope that many romance readers feel is overused.

Science Fiction

Science fiction stories can take place in the not-too-distant future or a long time ago in a galaxy far away. No matter when and where the story is set, there are certain tropes that readers look for.

Artificial Intelligence ‚Äì Given the recent headlines, it's no surprise that this trope is still going strong. AI can be helpful or hurtful in the story, but it's a staple of many a sci-fi story.

Dystopian ‚Äì Totalitarian governments and post-apocalyptic hellscapes make the backdrop for many dystopian stories. Often, the story involves the protagonist toppling the oppressive system.

Time Travel ‚Äì Enough said.

Space Travel ‚Äì Humans aren't meant to live in space. It's dangerous. Lots can go wrong.

Aliens ‚Äì Like Artificial Intelligence, Aliens can be allies, enemies, or even main characters. First Contact is a sci-fi subgenre about humanity's first contact with aliens.

Alternate Dimensions/Universes ‚Äì Doesn't have to be done just with superheroes. üòâ

Nanotech ‚Äì Little robots that do crazy things!

Implants ‚Äì Changes to human bodies that give strange abilities.

Power and Technology ‚Äì People want to use technology for evil, while others try to stop them and use it for good.

End of Human Race ‚Äì Unless the characters survive and procreate.

The Ticking Clock ‚Äì The sun will explode or the engines will fail or the asteroid will hit at a certain time.

Downloading People ‚Äì When the technology exists to have one‚Äôs consciousness downloaded.

Body Switching ‚Äì When characters can inhabit bodies other than their own.

Army of Clones

Destroying the Universe ‚Äì When a malevolent being wants to kill everything.

Dangers of Cryo Sleep ‚Äì A lot can go wrong when you sleep for decades.

Thriller & Suspense

Thriller and suspense tropes are often found in action & adventure, mystery, science fiction, and even fantasy stories.

Ticking Clock ‚Äì There's often a race against time in thrillers that adds suspense.

Troubled Protagonist ‚Äì Often a character with a background in law enforcement or the military, the protagonist is flawed and deeply troubled. All he or she has is the case or the mission.

The Unreliable Narrator ‚Äì Most common in psychological suspense or thrillers, the unreliable narrator often lies to the reader or tells half-truths. This can help with the next trope on the list.

The Twist Ending ‚Äì A good twist ending is hard to pull off, but you can do it with a careful hand. It helps to have red herrings and an unreliable narrator.

The Insurmountable Odds ‚Äì Unlike mysteries, thrillers often make no mystery as to who the villain is. The tension comes in the seemingly impossible odds the main character faces. How will they ever defeat the antagonist? Will they die in the process?

High Stakes ‚Äì At the very least, the protagonist's life is at stake. To raise the tension, put other people's lives at stake. Lots of them.

Exotic Locales ‚Äì Not every thriller needs to be a globe-trotting adventure, but many of them are. The main character often has to go to well-known cities around the world to stop the villain.

The Cliffhanger ‚Äì Much of the time at the end of a chapter, but sometimes at the end of a book.

Missing Children or Spouses

Gaslighting ‚Äì Often a theme in psychological suspense.

The Stalker

The Frame-Up ‚Äì Often ties in with the protagonist being suspected of the crime.

Crime in the Family ‚Äì When someone close to the protagonist commits a crime.

Young Adult

Young Adult novels like Harry Potter or The Hunger Games use different genres and tropes to tell their stories. Still, there are some common tropes you'll often see in these books no matter what the genre.

The Outsider ‚Äì The protagonist is often an outsider, going against the grain and preferring to do things their own way.

The First Love ‚Äì Young love is a common theme in these novels. It can be a subplot or even the driving force of the novel.

Love Is the Answer ‚Äì It doesn‚Äôt matter what the question is.

Incapable of Love ‚Äì That character who has been hurt so badly they‚Äôve given up on love. Until . . .

Useless or Evil Adults ‚Äì It's no surprise that books written about teenagers often portray adults as incompetent or evil. This trope may be overused and ripe for subverting the reader's expectations.

The Chosen One ‚Äì A protagonist that's prophesied to be the savior of Earth (or whatever fictional world the story is set on).

Dark Family Secret ‚Äì This trope can create tension and provide surprise.

Discovering Special Powers ‚Äì If the story is of a fantasy or paranormal type, this can happen to move the plot along.

The Missing or Absent Parents ‚Äì This trope is often about getting the adults out of the picture to increase tension and allow the main characters to deal with issues without the help of their parents.

A Complete List of Book Tropes: Conclusion

Tropes themselves aren't good or bad. While they're often referred to negatively and as something to avoid, there are reasons why you see some of them so often. Readers look for certain tropes and avoid others. It's up to you to read widely in your chosen genre and familiarize yourself with the common tropes.

This way, you can provide a unique twist or use them to subvert expectations in a good way. This can help provide readers with a unique story they will love!
